elements.content: A new three-dimensional europium-based metal–organic framework has been synthesized with the newly designed ligand L (6-[1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl]­nicotinic acid). This compound acts as a dual sensor for the phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion in aqueous media. The mechanistic aspect of this selectivity and sensitivity was explored through several spectroscopic methods and then correlated with the corresponding structure.
elements.clean_text: A new three-dimensional europium-based metal-organic framework has been synthesized with the newly designed ligand L (6-[1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl]nicotinic acid). This compound acts as a dual sensor for the phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion in aqueous media. The mechanistic aspect of this selectivity and sensitivity was explored through several spectroscopic methods and then correlated with the corresponding structure.

elements.content:
The europium-based metal−organic framework acts as a dual sensor for selective sensing of the phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media.

Phosphate plays a significant role in biological and environmental systems. Detection of the phosphate concentration in body fluids is essential for the diagnosis of severe diseases like vitamin D deficiency, Fanconi syndrome, and hyperparathyroidism. The increase in the concentration of inorganic phosphates in natural water will engender environmental issues such as eutrophication. Therefore, developing a selective and sensitive sensor for phosphate detection in aqueous media is noteworthy to protect the environment and human health. To do this, various analytical techniques have been developed including spectrophotometry, fluorometry, chromatography, and electrochemical analysis. Among these, fluorescent techniques have a substantial role in sensing applications because of their remarkable advantages such as their high level of sensitivity, specificity, fast response, and simplicity. The detection of phosphate ions in aqueous media is a difficult task because of their strong hydration effects. Therefore, the sensor probe should be stable and require suitable detecting sites in aqueous media.
elements.clean_text:
The europium-based metal-organic framework acts as a dual sensor for selective sensing of the phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media.

Phosphate plays a significant role in biological and environmental systems. Detection of the phosphate concentration in body fluids is essential for the diagnosis of severe diseases like vitamin D deficiency, Fanconi syndrome, and hyperparathyroidism. The increase in the concentration of inorganic phosphates in natural water will engender environmental issues such as eutrophication. Therefore, developing a selective and sensitive sensor for phosphate detection in aqueous media is noteworthy to protect the environment and human health. To do this, various analytical techniques have been developed including spectrophotometry, fluorometry, chromatography, and electrochemical analysis. Among these, fluorescent techniques have a substantial role in sensing applications because of their remarkable advantages such as their high level of sensitivity, specificity, fast response, and simplicity. The detection of phosphate ions in aqueous media is a difficult task because of their strong hydration effects. Therefore, the sensor probe should be stable and require suitable detecting sites in aqueous media.

elements.content: On the other hand, the Fe3+ ion plays a vital role in biological systems such as oxygen transport, synthesis of DNA and RNA, muscle and brain function, and hemoglobin formation. Moreover, an excess or a deficiency of iron severely affects the immune and enzyme systems, which can result in several pathological disorders like skin ailments and insomnia, iron deficiency anemia, mental decline, etc. Therefore, it is essential to develop an efficient sensor that can detect the Fe3+ ion in aqueous media. Reports on phosphate sensing using metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are rare. The detection of phosphate and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media using a single sensor would be an ideal choice for effectiveness and practical application.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the Fe3+ ion plays a vital role in biological systems such as oxygen transport, synthesis of DNA and RNA, muscle and brain function, and hemoglobin formation. Moreover, an excess or a deficiency of iron severely affects the immune and enzyme systems, which can result in several pathological disorders like skin ailments and insomnia, iron deficiency anemia, mental decline, etc. Therefore, it is essential to develop an efficient sensor that can detect the Fe3+ ion in aqueous media. Reports on phosphate sensing using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are rare. The detection of phosphate and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media using a single sensor would be an ideal choice for effectiveness and practical application.

elements.content: MOFs consist of metal nodes and organic ligands and attribute hierarchy of structures, high surface area, appropriate active sites, and chemical and thermal stability. Luminescent MOFs have been used as sensors because of their unique properties. Moreover, lanthanide MOFs (LnMOFs) are uniquely attractive for developing luminescent sensor probes because of their fascinating optical properties, i.e., large Stokes’ shifts, high optical purity and quantum yields, visualization, relatively long luminescence lifetimes, etc. Herein we report a europium-based MOF (compound 1) with a designed organic ligand (L; and Scheme S1). Compound 1 was synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of Eu­(NO3)3·5H2O and L in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) for 72 h at 120 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) experiments analyzed the colorless crystals of compound 1, and it was formulated as {Eu2L3(DMF)}·2DMF. Compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/c (No. 14). The asymmetric unit consists of two independent EuIII ions, three different ligands (L2–), and one coordinated DMF molecule. The carboxylate groups of ligand L have two types of binding modes in which one of the carboxylate groups belongs to the chelating–bridging mode and two different carboxylate groups adopt the chelating mode (Figure S1). Two independent europium metal ions (Eu1 and Eu2, respectively) are 8-coordinated and exhibit a bicapped tetragonal-prismatic geometry (Figure S2). In this, Eu1 is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from L2– ligands and one coordinated DMF molecule, whereas eight oxygen atoms from the carboxylate moieties coordinate with the Eu2 metal ion. The two carboxylate moieties are connected by two independent EuIII ions to generate a binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) with a Eu···Eu separation of 4.1314 (5) Å. Then another carboxylate moiety connects these SBUs to form a three-dimensional framework.
elements.clean_text: MOFs consist of metal nodes and organic ligands and attribute hierarchy of structures, high surface area, appropriate active sites, and chemical and thermal stability. Luminescent MOFs have been used as sensors because of their unique properties. Moreover, lanthanide MOFs (LnMOFs) are uniquely attractive for developing luminescent sensor probes because of their fascinating optical properties, i.e., large Stokes' shifts, high optical purity and quantum yields, visualization, relatively long luminescence lifetimes, etc. Herein we report a europium-based MOF (compound 1) with a designed organic ligand (L;  and Scheme S1). Compound 1 was synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of Eu(NO3)3⋅5H2O and L in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) for 72 h at 120 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) experiments analyzed the colorless crystals of compound 1, and it was formulated as {Eu2L3(DMF)}⋅2DMF. Compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system with space group P21/c (No. 14). The asymmetric unit consists of two independent EuIII ions, three different ligands (L2-), and one coordinated DMF molecule. The carboxylate groups of ligand L have two types of binding modes in which one of the carboxylate groups belongs to the chelating-bridging mode and two different carboxylate groups adopt the chelating mode (Figure S1). Two independent europium metal ions (Eu1 and Eu2, respectively) are 8-coordinated and exhibit a bicapped tetragonal-prismatic geometry (Figure S2). In this, Eu1 is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from L2- ligands and one coordinated DMF molecule, whereas eight oxygen atoms from the carboxylate moieties coordinate with the Eu2 metal ion. The two carboxylate moieties are connected by two independent EuIII ions to generate a binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) with a Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu separation of 4.1314 (5) Å. Then another carboxylate moiety connects these SBUs to form a three-dimensional framework.

elements.content: Molecular structure of ligand L.

It is interesting to note that the carboxylate groups are bound to EuIII ions, whereas the pyridyl groups of the ligand species are uncoordinated and freely accessible in the framework. The topology of compound 1 was represented as a 11,12-connected 2-nodal net with a point symbol of {318.433.54}­{318.436.58.64} ().
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that the carboxylate groups are bound to EuIII ions, whereas the pyridyl groups of the ligand species are uncoordinated and freely accessible in the framework. The topology of compound 1 was represented as a 11,12-connected 2-nodal net with a point symbol of {318.433.54}{318.436.58.64} ().

elements.content: (a) Three-dimensional view of compound 1. (b) Fragment of the two-dimensional arrangement of compound 1 along the ac plane. (c) Coordination environment of dinuclear EuIII metal ions in compound 1. (d) Topological representation of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Three-dimensional view of compound 1. (b) Fragment of the two-dimensional arrangement of compound 1 along the ac plane. (c) Coordination environment of dinuclear EuIII metal ions in compound 1. (d) Topological representation of compound 1.

elements.content: The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data are in good agreement, which confirmed the phase purity of the compound (Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis showed that the weight loss at 220 °C corresponded to the removal of coordinated DMF molecules, and then it was stable up to 340 °C. After that, the framework collapsed (Figure S4). We activated the compound through a solvent-exchange method (see the Supporting Information). After activation, the PXRD pattern of compound 1′ (activated compound) slightly shifted, and this may be due to the flexible nature of 1′. We have performed the SCXRD experiment for activated compound 1′. With the same space group, a slight change in the unit cell parameters confirmed that shifting of the PXRD pattern might arise from the flexible nature of the metal nodes or organic linker (see Table S3). We checked the stability of compound 1′ in aqueous media by immersing the crystals in a water medium for 3 days. Subsequently, we analyzed the PXRD pattern, which retains a crystallinity matching that of compound 1′ (Figure S3). We performed N2 adsorption for compound 1′ at 77 K. The isotherms showed a low Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 19 m2/g, and the pore-size (2.4 nm) distribution profile was calculated for the activated compound 1′ (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: The simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data are in good agreement, which confirmed the phase purity of the compound (Figure S3). Thermogravimetric analysis showed that the weight loss at 220 °C corresponded to the removal of coordinated DMF molecules, and then it was stable up to 340 °C. After that, the framework collapsed (Figure S4). We activated the compound through a solvent-exchange method (see the Supporting Information). After activation, the PXRD pattern of compound 1' (activated compound) slightly shifted, and this may be due to the flexible nature of 1'. We have performed the SCXRD experiment for activated compound 1'. With the same space group, a slight change in the unit cell parameters confirmed that shifting of the PXRD pattern might arise from the flexible nature of the metal nodes or organic linker (see Table S3). We checked the stability of compound 1' in aqueous media by immersing the crystals in a water medium for 3 days. Subsequently, we analyzed the PXRD pattern, which retains a crystallinity matching that of compound 1' (Figure S3). We performed N2 adsorption for compound 1' at 77 K. The isotherms showed a low Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 19 m2/g, and the pore-size (2.4 nm) distribution profile was calculated for the activated compound 1' (Figure S5).

elements.content: The ligand L absorbs at 270 and 295 nm, respectively, and emits at 345 nm under excitation at 295 nm in a DMF solvent (Figure S6). In the solid state, compound 1′ absorbs at 330 nm (Figure S7). The excitation spectra of 1′ were examined at the characteristic emission of 611 nm, which resulted in a broad band with a maximum peak at 345 nm (Figure S8a). Upon excitation at 330 nm, compound 1′ exhibits strong emissions in the visible region at 590, 611, 648, and 699 nm, which are attributed to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1–4) transitions of Eu3+ ions (Figure S8b). The unique optical properties and stability in aqueous media of the as-synthesized compound provoked us for the detection of pollutant anions in aqueous media. To do this, we carried out photoluminescence studies by the addition of various pollutant anions such as Cl–, Br–, NO3 –, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, CrO4 2–, Cr2O7 2–, P2O7 4–, HPO4 2–, H2PO4 –, and PO4 3– to the activated compound 1 in a 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES) buffer solution (pH = 7; Figure S9). With the addition of phosphate anions, the fluorescence intensity decreases, and no significant change was observed in the case of other pollutant anions (c). This confirms that compound 1′ can selectively detect phosphate anions in aqueous media (a). Moreover, we observed that 1′ acts as a chemosensor and the response time for sensing was 10 min. Later, we conducted interference experiments with other cointerfering anions (CO3 2–, SO4 2–, NO3 –, Br–, CrO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2–), and we observed that other anions have a minor effect on the quenching of 1′ (Figure S10). Quantitatively, the quenching efficiency effect was rationalized by the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[M], where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the interaction of compound 1′ with phosphate anions, respectively, [M] is the molar concentration of the phosphate anion, and K SV is the quenching effect coefficient (M–1). The S–V plot is nearly linear (R 2 = 0.967) in the range of 3–30 μM, and a high K SV value (4 × 104 M–1) was obtained that is comparable to those of known luminescent LnMOF sensors (Figure S11 and Table S4). The detection limit was calculated to be 6.62 μM, which is the relatively lowest concentration for the detection requirement of phosphate discharge criteria in the water environment, and the range is reported to be 6.4–320 μM.

In the solid state, compound 1' absorbs at 330 nm (Figure S7). The excitation spectra of 1' were examined at the characteristic emission of 611 nm, which resulted in a broad band with a maximum peak at 345 nm (Figure S8a). Upon excitation at 330 nm, compound 1' exhibits strong emissions in the visible region at 590, 611, 648, and 699 nm, which are attributed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 1-4) transitions of Eu3+ ions (Figure S8b). The unique optical properties and stability in aqueous media of the as-synthesized compound provoked us for the detection of pollutant anions in aqueous media. To do this, we carried out photoluminescence studies by the addition of various pollutant anions such as Cl-, Br-, NO3 -, SO4 2-, CO3 2-, CrO4 2-, Cr2O7 2-, P2O7 4-, HPO4 2-, H2PO4 -, and PO4 3- to the activated compound 1 in a 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES) buffer solution (pH = 7; Figure S9). Later, we conducted interference experiments with other cointerfering anions (CO3 2-, SO4 2-, NO3 -, Br-, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2-), and we observed that other anions have a minor effect on the quenching of 1' (Figure S10). Quantitatively, the quenching efficiency effect was rationalized by the Stern-Volmer (S-V) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[M], where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the interaction of compound 1' with phosphate anions, respectively, [M] is the molar concentration of the phosphate anion, and K SV is the quenching effect coefficient (M-1). The S-V plot is nearly linear (R 2 = 0.967) in the range of 3-30 μM, and a high K SV value (4 × 104 M-1) was obtained that is comparable to those of known luminescent LnMOF sensors (Figure S11 and Table S4). elements.content: Photoluminescence spectra of compound 1′ (a) at different concentrations of PO4 3– anions and (b) at different concentrations of Fe3+ ions. Fluorescence response of compound 1′ treated with various (c) anions (100 μL, 1 mM) and (d) metal ions (100 μL, 10–2 M) in a HEPES buffer solution (pH = 7).
elements.clean_text: 3  Photoluminescence spectra of compound 1' (a) at different concentrations of PO4 3- anions and (b) at different concentrations of Fe3+ ions. Fluorescence response of compound 1' treated with various (c) anions (100 μL, 1 mM) and (d) metal ions (100 μL, 10-2 M) in a HEPES buffer solution (pH = 7).

elements.content: In aqueous media, the selective detection of phosphate anions was attributed to their high hydration energy, with a high charge-to-radius ratio compared with other pollutant anions. Also, some other factors that can affect the anion binding are the geometry, charge of the anion, noncovalent interactions between the metal cluster and anion, nature of the solvent medium, and lability of the metal cluster. We carried out quenching studies by dissolving the anions in an isopropyl alcohol/water mixture (50:1, v/v; Figure S12). It was observed that the quenching efficiency of the phosphate anions decreased compared to that of aqueous media. This suggests that aqueous media are essential for phosphate sensing.
elements.clean_text: In aqueous media, the selective detection of phosphate anions was attributed to their high hydration energy, with a high charge-to-radius ratio compared with other pollutant anions. Also, some other factors that can affect the anion binding are the geometry, charge of the anion, noncovalent interactions between the metal cluster and anion, nature of the solvent medium, and lability of the metal cluster. We carried out quenching studies by dissolving the anions in an isopropyl alcohol/water mixture (50:1, v/v; Figure S12). It was observed that the quenching efficiency of the phosphate anions decreased compared to that of aqueous media. This suggests that aqueous media are essential for phosphate sensing.

elements.content: To investigate the possible mechanism for the sensing of phosphate with the current fluorescent probe, we conducted vibrational spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy showed that, upon the addition of low-to-high concentrations of phosphate anions to the framework of 1′, there is a decrease in the peak intensity of carboxylate C–O bonds, and further it disappears at high concentrations (1657 cm–1). Simultaneously, we observed a substantial rise in the peak intensity at 1642 cm–1, which corresponds to the stretching frequency of the P–O bonds (Figure S13). XPS data before and after phosphate addition revealed that there is a slight shift in the binding energy (Figure S14). This red shift in the 3d electron binding energy (that for Eu 3d3/2 is from 1136.19 to 1137.89 eV, and that for Eu 3d5/2 is from 1166.06 to 1167.35 eV) might be due to the interaction of phosphate groups with the europium center. The more electronegative P–O bonds leads to a loss electron density at the europium center, which, in turn, increases its 3d binding energy. These experimental investigations confirmed that the P–O bonds are interacting with the Eu–O cluster and thereby partial interruption of electron transfer between the organic ligand and metal center, which might be the reason for the decrease in the fluorescence intensity. We performed lifetime measurements, which indicated no change in the lifetimes before and after the addition of phosphate to 1′ (see Figure S15a). Also, we observed the change in the UV–visible absorption bands of 1′ after the addition of a phosphate (Figure S15b). It was concluded that quenching is due to the ground-state complex formation of phosphate with a fluorophore (1′). Hence, these analyses showed that phosphate sensing follows a static quenching process (Figure S15).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the possible mechanism for the sensing of phosphate with the current fluorescent probe, we conducted vibrational spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy showed that, upon the addition of low-to-high concentrations of phosphate anions to the framework of 1', there is a decrease in the peak intensity of carboxylate C-O bonds, and further it disappears at high concentrations (1657 cm-1). Simultaneously, we observed a substantial rise in the peak intensity at 1642 cm-1, which corresponds to the stretching frequency of the P-O bonds (Figure S13). XPS data before and after phosphate addition revealed that there is a slight shift in the binding energy (Figure S14). This red shift in the 3d electron binding energy (that for Eu 3d3/2 is from 1136.19 to 1137.89 eV, and that for Eu 3d5/2 is from 1166.06 to 1167.35 eV) might be due to the interaction of phosphate groups with the europium center. The more electronegative P-O bonds leads to a loss electron density at the europium center, which, in turn, increases its 3d binding energy. These experimental investigations confirmed that the P-O bonds are interacting with the Eu-O cluster and thereby partial interruption of electron transfer between the organic ligand and metal center, which might be the reason for the decrease in the fluorescence intensity. We performed lifetime measurements, which indicated no change in the lifetimes before and after the addition of phosphate to 1' (see Figure S15a). Also, we observed the change in the UV-visible absorption bands of 1' after the addition of a phosphate (Figure S15b). It was concluded that quenching is due to the ground-state complex formation of phosphate with a fluorophore (1'). Hence, these analyses showed that phosphate sensing follows a static quenching process (Figure S15).

elements.content: Further, compound 1 has a free pyridyl nitrogen atom and 1,2,3-triazole nitrogen atoms, which can act as Lewis basic sites. Also, the characteristic features of photoluminescence and water stability motivated us to check the sensing of metal ions in aqueous media. We studied the fluorescence sensing experiment by the addition of equal concentrations of various metal ions (10–2 M) such as Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ to a dispersion of the activated compound 1. Only the Fe3+ ion was selectively detected in compound 1′ (see b,d and S16). Moreover, the quenching efficiency was evaluated by the S–V equation with a linear correlation (R 2= 0.992) for I 0/I versus the concentration of Fe3+ ions. The K SV value was found to be 6 × 105 M–1, and the limit of detection was calculated to be 0.793 μM (Figure S17). It is comparable to other MOF materials with higher binding constants (Table S5). We carried out an interference experiment for Fe3+; it showed a minor effect on the luminescence quenching by Cr3+, Zn2+, and Cd2+, while other cations (Co2+, Fe2+, Cu2+, etc.) had a negligible effect on the quenching of 1′ (Figure S18). Three aspects that can iniate the quenching of luminescent MOFs by metal ions are as follows: (1) collapse of the framework; (2) binding of metal cations with the organic linker (energy-transfer mechanism); (3) an ion-exchange approach (replacement of the metal cations in the framework with targeted metal ions). Compound 1′ was immersed in a Fe3+ ion solution (10–2 M) for 24 h and then washed with ethanol several times. No change in the PXRD pattern after treatment with Fe3+ ions in water, which rules out collapse of the framework (Figure S19a). Then we measured the UV–visible spectra of various metal ions in aqueous media. The resulting Fe3+ absorption spectrum was overlapped with the ligand emission of compound 1′ (Figures S19b and S19c). It is strongly evident that fluorescence quenching is due to the competition between the absorbance of the Fe3+ solution and the emission of compound 1′. Also, we performed lifetime measurements of 1′ before and after the addition of Fe3+ metal ions, which shown at 35.6 and 29.11 ns, respectively (Figure S19d). The change in the lifetimes also concluded that the quenching of 1′ was more likely to be a dynamic process. To underscore the interaction between the framework and Fe3+ ions; we collected the XPS data. This showed that the binding energy of N 1s of the pyridyl and triazole nitrogen atoms slightly shifted to higher energy (Figure S20). This shift in the binding energy could be due to the interaction of Fe3+ ions with the pyridyl and triazolyl nitrogen atoms. This coordination interaction of the Fe3+ ions with the framework reduces the antenna efficiency of ligand L2– to f–f transitions of Eu3+, thereby quenching the luminescence intensity.

Also, the characteristic features of photoluminescence and water stability motivated us to check the sensing of metal ions in aqueous media. We studied the fluorescence sensing experiment by the addition of equal concentrations of various metal ions (10-2 M) such as Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Al3+, and Fe3+ to a dispersion of the activated compound 1. Only the Fe3+ ion was selectively detected in compound 1' (see b,d and S16). Moreover, the quenching efficiency was evaluated by the S-V equation with a linear correlation (R 2= 0.992) for I 0/I versus the concentration of Fe3+ ions. The K SV value was found to be 6 × 105 M-1, and the limit of detection was calculated to be 0.793 μM (Figure S17). It is comparable to other MOF materials with higher binding constants (Table S5). We carried out an interference experiment for Fe3+; it showed a minor effect on the luminescence quenching by Cr3+, Zn2+, and Cd2+, while other cations (Co2+, Fe2+, Cu2+, etc.) had a negligible effect on the quenching of 1' (Figure S18). This coordination interaction of the Fe3+ ions with the framework reduces the antenna efficiency of ligand L2- to f-f transitions of Eu3+, thereby quenching the luminescence intensity.

elements.content: In conclusion, we synthesized a new three-dimensional europium-based framework structure with the newly designed 1,2,3-triazole-based nicotinic acid (L). The polyhedral unit of europium metal ions are linked to form the dimeric unit, and these dimeric units are connected with the carboxylate group to form the three-dimensional architecture. In compound 1, the pyridyl and triazole nitrogen atoms are uncoordinated and freely accessible for further functionalization. This MOF can selectively detect phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media. The interaction between the europium metal center and phosphate anions is responsible for the selective and sensitive detection of phosphate anions, while Fe3+ selective detection is accountable for binding of these ions with the pyridyl and triazole nitrogen atoms. There are a few reports on separate phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion sensing in aqueous media using MOF materials. However, reports on the dual sensing of phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media are rare. To our knowledge, this EuMOF is one of the rare compounds that can act as a dual sensor for the phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion in aqueous media.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we synthesized a new three-dimensional europium-based framework structure with the newly designed 1,2,3-triazole-based nicotinic acid (L). The polyhedral unit of europium metal ions are linked to form the dimeric unit, and these dimeric units are connected with the carboxylate group to form the three-dimensional architecture. In compound 1, the pyridyl and triazole nitrogen atoms are uncoordinated and freely accessible for further functionalization. This MOF can selectively detect phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media. The interaction between the europium metal center and phosphate anions is responsible for the selective and sensitive detection of phosphate anions, while Fe3+ selective detection is accountable for binding of these ions with the pyridyl and triazole nitrogen atoms. There are a few reports on separate phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion sensing in aqueous media using MOF materials. However, reports on the dual sensing of phosphate anions and Fe3+ ions in aqueous media are rare. To our knowledge, this EuMOF is one of the rare compounds that can act as a dual sensor for the phosphate anion and Fe3+ ion in aqueous media.

cln_elements.content: Photoluminescence spectra of compound 1′ (a) at different concentrations of PO4 3– anions and (b) at different concentrations of Fe3+ ions. Fluorescence response of compound 1′ treated with various (c) anions (100 μL, 1 mM) and (d) metal ions (100 μL, 10–2 M) in a HEPES buffer solution (pH = 7).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Photoluminescence spectra of compound 1' (a) at different concentrations of PO4 3- anions and (b) at different concentrations of Fe3+ ions. Fluorescence response of compound 1' treated with various (c) anions (100 μL, 1 mM) and (d) metal ions (100 μL, 10-2 M) in a HEPES buffer solution (pH = 7).

metadata.title:
Europium-Based Metal–Organic Framework as a
Dual Luminescence Sensor for the Selective Detection of the Phosphate
Anion and Fe3+ Ion in Aqueous Media
